misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when performing sequential modifications on a string (like uppercasing followed by replacement), the intermediate result of the first method call (i.e., the uppercase string) must be explicitly assigned to a new, named variable (`upperLine`) before the second method call (`replace()`) can be invoked. They view string processing as strictly a step-by-step procedure requiring explicit variable assignment for every transformation.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student's model restricts the flow of object references. In Java, methods like `toUpperCase()` return a new String object reference. This reference can immediately be used to call subsequent String methods (method chaining), such as `inputLine.toUpperCase().replace(" ", "_")`. The required explicit intermediate assignment (`upperLine` in this case) suggests a misunderstanding of how the return value of an object method can be immediately utilized.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Non-optimal code structure (excessive intermediate variables) leading to slightly more verbose code, but no functional error.
